For this NeuroView, we will provide a brief background of the Brain Bee and some examples of the ways individual countries have developed their own Brain Bee competitions; outline some of the ways the new IBB organization aims to provide infrastructure to align the local, national, and International Brain Bee efforts; and close with opportunities for individuals to get involved in the Brain Bee initiative. The Brain Bee is the brainchild of Dr. Norbert Myslinski, a professor in the University of Maryland’s Department of Neural Pain Sciences with a passion for teaching about the human brain. He founded the Brain Bee as a high school competition to inspire teenagers to learn more about clinical and behavioral brain sciences and to encourage them to enter a career in neuroscience or medicine. The first Brain Bee had both US and Canada representation and was held in 1999 in Baltimore. The Brain Bee Championship continued to be held as a US-Canada competition in Baltimore, then moved off US soil to Montreal, Canada in 2008. This first international competition had four national champions from the US, Canada, India, and Australia/New Zealand. That event was held in conjunction with the Canadian Annual Neuroscience Meeting and was hosted by the Canadian Association for Neuroscience and the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR). Over the next 10-year period, other countries started hosting their own national Brain Bees to select representatives to compete at the World Championship. Today, the local, national, and international Brain Bee competitions engage over 25,000 high-school-aged students from around the world each year. As more countries held Brain Bees, the World Championships began traveling the globe, occurring in conjunction with major neuroscience meetings throughout the world. The organizing committees are mostly comprised of volunteer college and university neuroscientists, graduate students, and high school teachers. Since the first IBB World Championship in Canada in 2008, the event has been held in multiple countries, including South Africa (International Congress of Psychology), Australia (International Society for Neurochemistry-Australasian Neuroscience Society Annual Meeting), Austria (World Congress of Neurology), Denmark and Germany (FENS Forum of Neuroscience), and Italy and South Korea (IBRO World Congress of Neuroscience). The American Psychological Association has hosted four IBB World Championships at its annual convention in Canada and the US. Brain Bees are an important educational and outreach tool that impacts individuals far beyond the national champions that make it to the World Championship. In many instances, high schools and other youth-oriented groups (scouting troops or local clubs) organize teams where students find a community to study and get guidance from teachers and other adult leaders to prepare for local and national competitions. Some high schools have Brain Bee content integrated into curriculum and use it to help teach about science careers. In Australia and New Zealand (where it is known as the Brain Bee Challenge), the Brain Bee plays a role in general scientific knowledge and helping to dispel myths around neurological and mental illnesses. It also serves as an opportunity for outreach to students living in remote and rural areas. In the United States, most local and national competitions are hosted by colleges, typically through psychology, biology, or neuroscience departments. They are key outreach opportunities for institutions and ways to promote their academic programs. Quite often, Brain Bees involve both undergraduate and graduate students, providing opportunities to develop important organizational, teaching, and science communication skills in the process. Established faculty and younger researchers (postdoctoral fellows) are recruited as judges and interact directly with competitors. Many research societies, foundations, and governmental agencies provide needed support for local and national Brain Bees. For example, the Canadian National Brain Bee is supported by the Canadian Institutes of Health Research and hosted at McMasters University. It is the culmination of numerous local Brain Bees throughout the Canadian provinces, where students compete and qualify. Another example is the Mongolian Brain Bee, which is relatively new and receives support from The Ministry of Education, Culture, Science, and Sport; The Mongolian National University of Medical Sciences; and the Mongolian Neuroscience Society. The growth of Brain Bees around the world and the annual hosting of a World Championship is impressive, given that in the past, all the work was done by an informal global network of volunteers. In 2018, the IBB celebrated its 20th anniversary, and in that same year, five major brain research and science organizations (the American Psychological Association, the Dana Foundation, the Federation of European Neuroscience Societies [FENS], the International Brain Research Organization [IBRO], and the Society for Neuroscience [SfN]) came together to establish a registered educational non-profit known as the International Brain Bee (https://thebrainbee.org/). The IBB Board is comprised of representatives of the five organizations plus Dr. Myslinski. All five governing partners renewed their initial 3-year commitment at the end of 2020 and recently welcomed the Alzheimer’s Association as an additional partner. Currently there are two part-time staff members (an Executive Director and an Academic Director) responsible for the coordination with national Brain Bees and the organization of the annual IBB World Championships. The goal of the new organization is to build upon the past success and momentum of Brain Bees and ensure the longevity of the IBB World Championships as an international platform for educators and scientists from around the world to introduce young minds to neuroscience. In 2020, the Board created two standing committees, one that focuses on partnership development and fundraising and a second that oversees the competition rules, regulations, and academic content of the IBB World Championship. Efforts are underway to establish partnerships with scientific research institutes, research societies/associations, and technology-based educational companies to create resources that will serve as preparation materials for IBB World Championship qualifiers. The creation of a deep test-bank of questions and use of cloud-based practice materials will allow for the tracking of which questions students master and ongoing learning analytics. Probably of greater impact to the actual competitors is the establishment of two broad learning outcomes for the World Championships: to create an academic competition that exposes participants to the cutting edge and diverse applications of neuroscience research, along with encouraging ongoing study and careers in neuroscience, and to integrate a social program that provides opportunities for competitors to share and learn about their different cultures. The academic competition takes about two days to complete and follows a standard format with five subsections that test students’ knowledge and understanding of neuroanatomy, histology (Figure 1A), clinical applications through patient diagnosis, a written multiple-choice and short-answer exam, and a final live-answer Q&A session, which is usually held at the hosting conference and open to the public. Currently, content is primarily drawn from three sources (BrainFacts from the Society for Neuroscience; Essential Neuroscience by Siegel and Sapru; and The Brain: An Introduction to Functional Neuroanatomy by Watson, Paxinos, and Kirkcaldie). For each World Championship, the organizing committee must pass along what worked well from year-to-year, what questions were used, and how competitors fared on each question. For many competitors, the IBB World Championship is the first time they have traveled outside their country, and the IBB organizers have taken advantage of this opportunity to create a cultural exchange and unique friendship experience. The social program provides time for students to socialize and learn from one another: for example, it has become a tradition for each competitor to bring a souvenir from his or her country and explain why they think it represents the history and culture of their country. Interspersed between the academic components of the competition, participants get to tour their host city, attend scientific sessions of the host meeting, and have unstructured social time and gather for an awards ceremony and dinner before heading home (Figure 1C). Past Brain Bee competitors stay connected with one another through various forums such as dedicated Facebook groups and other social media platforms. Many former Brain Bee competitors join the International Youth Neuroscience Association (INYA), a separate nonprofit with 175 chapters in 80 countries that is organized and led mainly by high school and college students. The INYA is an active partner of the IBB and provides assistance in numerous ways, from helping to recruit IBB interns, helping prepare Brain Bee competitors, and assisting with the creation of study materials that can be provided to local and national Brain Bees. The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in some of the local and national Brain Bees being held virtually, while other Brain Bees and the 2020 IBB World Championship were cancelled altogether. For 2021, most national Brain Bees and the IBB itself are planning virtual events. Hosting a completely virtual IBB World Championship presents unique challenges (e.g., securing the questions and competition content when delivered asynchronously across multiple time zones and delivering an engaging, virtual social program). Doing so, however, will advance the development of an interactive, online platform that can be used by Brain Bees in the future to complement their own competitions and as a study and practice platform for competitors. The IBB Board anticipates and is currently planning a fully in-person IBB World Championship in Paris, France to be hosted by the 2022 FENS Forum of Neuroscience. The growth and success of the entire Brain Bee program—from local chapters to the production of the annual IBB World Championship—relies upon a network of highly committed volunteers from around the world. Chances are there is a Brain Bee near you, and if you are a scientist, educator, or an advocate of science education, we welcome your involvement! Volunteer opportunities range from being judges for competitions, hosting and organizing a competition, or starting a new Brain Bee. You can find local and national Brain Bees online through Facebook or other social media. The IBB website (https://thebrainbee.org/) maintains a list of countries that host Brain Bee competitions and their contact information. Several new national Brain Bees are currently in development, and we look to further expand our global reach by increasing the number of countries that send their champions to the annual IBB World Championship and by recruiting new countries. With thousands of students participating in local, national, and international competitions every year, Brain Bee alumni represent a valuable source of advocates. Former contestants are enthusiastic spokespeople for the Brain Bee initiative, and many have continued in careers of medicine and neuroscience research, policy, and education. Tracking and connecting Brain Bee alumni is a priority for the IBB, and we have created an alumni category on the IBB website. If you are a national Brain Bee coordinator, you can provide a list of your Brain Bee alumni. If you are a former competitor, we encourage you to sign up and answer a few questions about your experience and how the Brain Bee has influenced your career trajectory. We have several interns who assist with alumni tracking who may reach out to you to conduct an interview. Alumni stories will be featured and communicated in a variety of ways to help promote the impact of the IBB and to assist with partnership development and fundraising. Other organizations provide financial and in-kind support of the IBB World Championships. For example, Leadership Initiatives (DC) provides fully paid scholarships to IBB Champions to participate in their neuroscience internship programs hosted in collaboration with Georgetown University, offering further exposure to neuroscience research. Elsevier has provided national champions with copies of one of the study books. We welcome other organizations, companies, and foundations to explore future sponsorship or partnerships that extend the Brain Bee community or help support the development of the IBB World Championship. To learn more about any of these ways to be involved in Brain Bees, whether you’re an alumnus, an educator looking to volunteer, or an organization or foundation seeking partnership ideas, please contact Astrid Eberhart, IBB Executive Director, at [email protected] . However, the simplest way to support the Brain Bee initiative is to help us spread the word. If you are a science educator, we encourage you to let others know about the IBB, including students who may wish to participate. If you are a science advocate, come see a Brain Bee in action. As mentioned earlier, most competitions—including the IBB World Championships—allow spectators to attend the live judging component. Whether you are an active member of the Brain Bee community or taking your first step into the Brain Bee world, we hope to see you at a future Brain Bee competition. Garth A. Neonatal deaths represent around half the deaths of children less than five-years old in Cambodia. The process from live birth to neonatal death has not been well described. This study aimed to identify problems in health care service which hamper the reduction of preventable neonatal deaths in rural Cambodia.This study adopted a method of qualitative case study design using narrative data from the verbal autopsy standard. Eighty and forty villages were randomly selected from Kampong Cham and Svay Rieng provinces, respectively. All households in the target villages were visited between January and February 2017. Family caregivers were asked to describe their experiences on births and neonatal deaths between 2015 and 2016. Information on the process from birth to death was extracted with open coding, categorized, and summarized into several groups which represent potential problems in health services.Among a total of 4,142 children born in 2015 and 2016, 35 neonatal deaths were identified. Of these deaths, 74% occurred within one week of birth, and 57% were due to low-birth weight. Narrative data showed that three factors should be improved, 1) the unavailability of a health-care professional, 2) barriers in the referral system, and 3) lack of knowledge and skill to manage major causes of neonatal deaths.The current health system has limitations to achieve further reduction of neonatal deaths in rural Cambodia. The mere deployment of midwives at fixed service points such as health centers could not solve the problems occurring in rural communities. Community engagement revisiting the principle of primary health care, as well as health system transformation, is the key to the solution and potential breakthrough for the future.
